prompt:
My Roommate's Arrest

Part 1

You're grabbing lunch with a group of friends—Jordan>, Alex>, and Jamie>. The conversation turns to current events after Jordan brings up a headline in the news.
    Jordan:> Hey, did you guys hear that my former roommate was arrested last night?! Crazy, right?
      You:> No way! What happened?
    Jordan:> Apparently, my old roommate was at a party. This drunk chick starts dancing all close and coming on strong, you know? Well, they went back to his room and had sex. Three days later, she went to the police saying it was sexual assault.
    Alex:> That's so messed up. You can't just change your mind like that. Sounds like another female who regrets her bad decisions.
    Jamie:> Yeah, what's up with girls getting trashed, hanging all over guys, and then crying rape? I mean, if she didn't want it, why did she let him take her to a room?
question: Active bystanders are motivated to take responsibility in risky situations. What is one positive outcome that could result when a bystander intervenes in situations like this?
students_answer: Not spreading rumors on conjecture .
categories: Building Bystander Skills & Confidence|Bystander Avoidance / Diffusion of Responsibility|Changing Perpetrator Behavior & Attitudes|Cultural or Peer-Norm Justification|Fear of Negative Consequences (Social / Professional)|Inspiring Collective Action|Lack of Confidence / Learned Helplessness|Minimizing or Dismissing Harm|Perpetrator-Excusing|Preventing Future Harms|Protecting Teams|Recognition and Rewards for the Bystander|Shaping Norms & Culture Change|Supporting the Victim|Victim-blaming

prompt:
My Roommate's Arrest

Part 1

You're grabbing lunch with a group of friends—Jordan>, Alex>, and Jamie>. The conversation turns to current events after Jordan brings up a headline in the news.
    Jordan:> Hey, did you guys hear that my former roommate was arrested last night?! Crazy, right?
      You:> No way! What happened?
    Jordan:> Apparently, my old roommate was at a party. This drunk chick starts dancing all close and coming on strong, you know? Well, they went back to his room and had sex. Three days later, she went to the police saying it was sexual assault.
    Alex:> That's so messed up. You can't just change your mind like that. Sounds like another female who regrets her bad decisions.
    Jamie:> Yeah, what's up with girls getting trashed, hanging all over guys, and then crying rape? I mean, if she didn't want it, why did she let him take her to a room?
lockquote>

Part 2 - Scroll to continue reading

While you've always considered yourself a good friend and someone who stands up for what's right, you're struggling with what to do in this situation. Jordan>, your closest friend, has a habit of joking about sensitive topics without realizing the impact, so he probably didn't mean any harm.

You don't want to make things awkward, especially because everyone is laughing and doesn't seem bothered. Another friend's sister was sexually assaulted and died by suicide last year, so you know this is a serious issue.

You want to say something, but Alex> is known for being defensive when challenged especially in a group setting, and Jamie> has always been a jerk, often dismisses situations as "overblown" or as “just a joke.”
question: Imagine you decide the best course of action is to say something directly to the group. What do you say?
students_answer: That we should not be gossiping it does more harm than good.

prompt:
Showing Gratitude

Part 1

You work in a warehouse. While organizing inventory, you overhear a conversation between SrA Johnson> (your friend and coworker) and 1stLt Franco> (your leader). At first, the conversation seems like normal business talk, but soon the tone changes.
    SrA Johnson:> If I fail this review, then I don't get a promotion, and I'll be reassigned OCONUS.
      1stLt Franco:> I hear you, Johnson, but sometimes, it's not just about the work. There are... other ways to get ahead around here. You know what I mean?
    SrA Johnson:> No, what do you mean?
      1stLt Franco:> Listen, I've got influence around here. I can pull some strings to move you up the ranks, but you'd need to... show me some gratitude. This is just how things are done around here.
    SrA Johnson:> It sounds like you're suggesting…
      1stLt Franco (cuts him off):> Look, you're a smart guy, Johnson. I know what you want, and you know what I want. We can make an arrangement that helps us both get “a head”.
question: Active bystanders are motivated to take responsibility in risky situations. What is one positive outcome that could result when a bystander intervenes in situations like this?
students_answer: Better safer workplace, stop a non-censual sexual encounter.

lockquote>

Part 2 - Scroll to continue reading

You're still processing what you overheard. 1stLt Franco's> offer about "showing gratitude" in exchange for a promotion seems coercive, but you're unsure whether to intervene. 1stLt Franco> is influential within the team and a higher rank than you and SrA Johnson>. You're worried that saying something could cause serious professional consequences.

Even though SrA Johnson> is gay, 1stLt Franco> is a total “ladies' man”, so it's hard to picture him asking SrA Johnson> for sexual favors. Plus, you were eavesdropping. Maybe you didn't hear things correctly?

question: Imagine you decide the best course of action is to say something directly to either SrA Johnson or 1stLt Franco. Who do you speak to and what do you say?
students_answer: i would confront 1st Lt Franco directly but i would consult Johnson to go seek help from either the chapel, first sergeant or Hawks cove SAPR

prompt:
Dancing at the Club

Part 1

It's Friday night and you're getting drinks with your friends Ken> and Megan> after work. Jacob>, a buddy from high school, walks in and you invite him to hang out with the group.

Everyone is chatting and getting along. You all decide to go to a second location—a nearby club. The music is loud, everyone's drinking, and the vibe is fun.

Megan> and Jacob> are hitting it off, and you sense chemistry between them. As the night goes on, Jacob> becomes increasingly close to Megan>, first by putting his arms around Megan's> shoulders, then touching her thighs repeatedly. Megan> keeps looking at you> and Ken>, almost as if she's seeking reassurance, but she never pulls away from Jacob>.

Ken> notices Megan's> body language and leans over to you.
    Ken:> Hey, do you think Megan's> okay with Jacob>
      You:> I'm not sure. They look fine to me.
    Ken:> It looks weird to me. Jacob's> being really handsy, and Megan> doesn't seem into it.
question: Active bystanders are motivated to take responsibility in risky situations. What is one positive outcome that could result when a bystander intervenes in situations like this?
students_answer: Megan could have an opportunity to vocalize her feelings about what is happening to her.  If she is uncomfortable, you can step in to assist her.  If she doesn't vocalize it, you can still step in and separate her from him to check in.
categories: Building Bystander Skills & Confidence|Bystander Avoidance / Diffusion of Responsibility|Changing Perpetrator Behavior & Attitudes|Cultural or Peer-Norm Justification|Fear of Negative Consequences (Social / Professional)|Inspiring Collective Action|Lack of Confidence / Learned Helplessness|Minimizing or Dismissing Harm|Perpetrator-Excusing|Preventing Future Harms|Protecting Teams|Recognition and Rewards for the Bystander|Shaping Norms & Culture Change|Supporting the Victim|Victim-blaming

prompt:
Dancing at the Club

Part 1

It's Friday night and you're getting drinks with your friends Ken> and Megan> after work. Jacob>, a buddy from high school, walks in and you invite him to hang out with the group.

Everyone is chatting and getting along. You all decide to go to a second location—a nearby club. The music is loud, everyone's drinking, and the vibe is fun.

Megan> and Jacob> are hitting it off, and you sense chemistry between them. As the night goes on, Jacob> becomes increasingly close to Megan>, first by putting his arms around Megan's> shoulders, then touching her thighs repeatedly. Megan> keeps looking at you> and Ken>, almost as if she's seeking reassurance, but she never pulls away from Jacob>.

Ken> notices Megan's> body language and leans over to you.
    Ken:> Hey, do you think Megan's> okay with Jacob>
      You:> I'm not sure. They look fine to me.
    Ken:> It looks weird to me. Jacob's> being really handsy, and Megan> doesn't seem into it.
lockquote>

Part 2 - Scroll to continue reading

You think that Ken> is reading too much into the situation and interpret the situation differently. Jacob> is an old fiend, and he doesn't mean any harm. He's just drinking and having a good time with a pretty girl.

Plus, you believe Megan> would speak up for herself if someone crossed a line. On the other hand, Megan> has been drinking, so maybe you should step in? You worry that if you're wrong, then Megan> will think you don't trust her judgment or that she needs saving because she's a girl.

It feels like you're walking a fine line. A part of you wonders if you should just let Ken> handle it since he's the one who is so concerned.
question: Active bystanders decide how to act in a risky situation based on what they know about a situation and the people involved. After reading part 2 of the scenario, identify two acceptable ways to respond in this situation.
students_answer: Ask Megan to go to the restroom with you and ask her how she is feeling.  Ask Ken to take Jacob away so you can talk with Megan.
categories: Aggressive|Avoidant|Delay|Delegate|Direct|Distract|Document

prompt:
A Private Conversation

Part 1

You are stationed at a military base working with SSgt Quinn>, Amn James>, and Amn Brown>. You notice SSgt Quinn> and Amn James> step into the hallway for a private conversation. At first, it seems like normal work talk, until you overhear SSgt Quinn's> comment.
    SSgt Quinn (to Amn James):> I am a sexual being. Some things cannot be controlled.
      Amn James laughs nervously at SSgt Quinn.
The exchange sounds off, but you're on a deadline, so you ask Amn Brown> to check on things. Amn Brown> steps out into the hall when you hear a struggle, presumably between SSgt Quinn> and Amn James>. Amn Brown> returns to say:
    Amn Brown (to you):> I don't know what exactly happened, but SSgt Quinn> pinned Amn James> against the wall and grabbed his crotch. He pushed her away, and SSgt Quinn> walked off like it was nothing!
question: Active bystanders are motivated to take responsibility in risky situations. What is one positive outcome that could result when a bystander intervenes in situations like this?
students_answer: Amn James feels protected, safe, and seen.  Amn Brown will know that this type of behavior is absolutely unacceptable.

Just then, Amn James> returns to the workspace, visibly shaken.
    Amn James (to Adm Brown):> You ok, man?
    Amn Brown (to Amn James and you):> I'm fine. I'm taking my lunch break now.

students_answer: As a supervisor, I would immediately respond to Amn Browns comment that I do believe Amn James and we will support him.  I would contact Amn James immediately to ask him to meet me somewhere where he felt comfortable to discuss what happened and what his options are.  I would contact SSgt Quinn and address the comment I overheard and what I understood to have happened in the hallway.  I would then report this incident up the chain of command.

prompt:

You work in a warehouse. While organizing inventory, you overhear a conversation between SrA Johnson> (your friend and coworker) and 1stLt Franco> (your leader). At first, the conversation seems like normal business talk, but soon the tone changes.

You're worried that saying something could cause serious professional consequences.

prompt:
Dancing at the Club

Part 1

It's Friday night and you're getting drinks with your friends Ken> and Megan> after work. Jacob>, a buddy from high school, walks in and you invite him to hang out with the group.

Everyone is chatting and getting along. You all decide to go to a second location—a nearby club. The music is loud, everyone's drinking, and the vibe is fun.

Megan> and Jacob> are hitting it off, and you sense chemistry between them. As the night goes on, Jacob> becomes increasingly close to Megan>, first by putting his arms around Megan's> shoulders, then touching her thighs repeatedly. Megan> keeps looking at you> and Ken>, almost as if she's seeking reassurance, but she never pulls away from Jacob>.

Ken> notices Megan's> body language and leans over to you.
    Ken:> Hey, do you think Megan's> okay with Jacob>
      You:> I'm not sure. They look fine to me.
    Ken:> It looks weird to me. Jacob's> being really handsy, and Megan> doesn't seem into it.
question: Active bystanders are motivated to take responsibility in risky situations. What is one positive outcome that could result when a bystander intervenes in situations like this?
students_answer: The uncomfortable touches could cease and you can help Megan feel more comfortable, also knowing you're a safe person to be out with.

prompt:
My Roommate's Arrest

Part 1

You're grabbing lunch with a group of friends—Jordan>, Alex>, and Jamie>. The conversation turns to current events after Jordan brings up a headline in the news.
    Jordan:> Hey, did you guys hear that my former roommate was arrested last night?! Crazy, right?
      You:> No way! What happened?
    Jordan:> Apparently, my old roommate was at a party. This drunk chick starts dancing all close and coming on strong, you know? Well, they went back to his room and had sex. Three days later, she went to the police saying it was sexual assault.
    Alex:> That's so messed up. You can't just change your mind like that. Sounds like another female who regrets her bad decisions.
    Jamie:> Yeah, what's up with girls getting trashed, hanging all over guys, and then crying rape? I mean, if she didn't want it, why did she let him take her to a room?
question: Active bystanders are motivated to take responsibility in risky situations. What is one positive outcome that could result when a bystander intervenes in situations like this?
students_answer: Could talk to the group about consent, the language they are using to describe the situations, and how victims are often afraid to speak up after an assault. Trying to give the group some perspective on the situation and how they are viewing it.

Part 2 - Scroll to continue reading

While you've always considered yourself a good friend and someone who stands up for what's right, you're struggling with what to do in this situation. Jordan>, your closest friend, has a habit of joking about sensitive topics without realizing the impact, so he probably didn't mean any harm.

question: Active bystanders decide how to act in a risky situation based on what they know about a situation and the people involved. After reading part 2 of the scenario, identify two acceptable ways to respond in this situation.
students_answer:
Option 1: Address the group directly, challenging them on how they are talking about the situation and women in general. 
Option 2: Talk to each person individually, which might make for a more impactful conversation. 
Option 3: redirect the conversation to a different topic.
